awd_titl_txt: CAREER: An Integrated Scheduling Framework for Multicore Based Real-Time Embedded Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this CAREER project is to design and develop an integrated scheduling framework for networked multicore-based control systems in smart vehicles. The advanced functionalities (such as stability control and collision avoidance) in modern vehicles impose high computational demand on their electronic control systems, which can be powered by multicore processors to mitigate their increasing complexity. However, the existing scheduling theory and techniques have fallen short of supporting such networked multicore-based control systems, especially considering the human-related factors and dynamic environments of smart vehicles.

This project undertakes a comprehensive study of resource management techniques and scheduling algorithms to efficiently schedule various real-time applications and effectively utilize the computation power in networked multicore-based smart vehicle control systems. First, a  hierarchical control architecture with a simplified high-level master controller is being investigated to achieve accurate situational awareness and ensure prompt response. Second, to address the uncertainty in dynamic environment, distributed and multicore-aware elastic real-time scheduling algorithms are being developed that can adaptively adjust the invocation interval of various control tasks for schedulability and stability. Moreover, criticality-aware scheduling algorithms are being developed that consider the variable importance of control tasks under different situations. Finally, energy-efficient multicore scheduling algorithms and battery management schemes for hybrid/electric smart vehicles are being investigated.

The design and development of the proposed scheduling framework has a direct economic and societal impact, which can reduce car accidents and thus save lives. Moreover, with the development of new curricula on cyber-physical systems, this project also provides abundant topics and learning opportunities for under-represented students.

por.por_cntn:
In modern automobiles, the number of computerized electronic control units (ECUs) that control engine, breaks, and entertainment systems can be as high as 100 or more. Such large number of ECUs makes the design of automobile control systems more complex and impose additional cost for consumers. Multicore processors have become the de facto computing engines for computer systems, and it is expected that such processors will be widely deployed in the control systems for smart automobiles to support the ever-increasing computational demand and reduce the complexity and cost by consolidating the large number of electronic control units (EUCs). Towards this direction, in this project, we have studied resource management techniques and scheduling algorithms to efficiently utilize the computation power in multicore-based control systems for supporting various control functions (such as engine control and ABS) with different levels of importance (or criticality) in modern smart automobiles.

First, we have developed an elastic scheduling framework (including task model and several scheduling algorithms) for mixed-criticality systems. Here, the objective is to provide continuous (though degraded) services for low-criticality tasks (such as telematics functions) while providing guaranteed services for high-criticality tasks (such as ABS) when a system enters high-critical (i.e., emergency) operation mode. Second, we studied a preference-oriented scheduling framework that can effectively handle the execution preferences of tasks, where some are executed at a later time to allow more urgent tasks run first without missing the deadlines of all tasks. Moreover, we investigated various techniques to improve performance, energy efficiency and system reliability for multicore based computing systems with their intriguing implications being considered.

This project also provides great training opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate students. Three PhD students (including one female) have been supported where two graduated in 2013 and 2015, respectively. Also, four undergraduate students (including one female and two Hispanic students) were supported by this project and associated REU supplement. Moreover, some developed scheduling techniques (such as preference-oriented scheduling and elastic mixed-criticality scheduling) have been included in a graduate course on advanced operating systems.

In summary, as the outcomes of this project, two PhD dissertation theses were completed. We also published 13 journal articles, 16 conference papers and three technical reports.
